Package com.siperian.sif.client Description

API to execute SIF requests on a remote Siperian Hub Server using a single class, SiperianClient, that abstracts a choice of protocols: EJB, SOAP, and HTTP.

The advantages of the EJB protocol are performance and the ability to use client transactions; multiple requests can be grouped for commit or rollback. The SiperianClient and EjbSiperianClient classes wrap the EJB remote interfaces (which should not be used directly). You are strongly discouraged from writing explicit transaction code if it can be avoided. The J2EE/EJB specification supports container-managed transactions (CMT) so such explicit coding isn't required. For more information about transactions, see the javadocs for EjbSiperianClient.

Transaction support is only available with the EJB protocol. All other protocols (including EJB if client transactions are not used) result in the Siperian Hub Server using its own autonomous transaction for each request.

XML over HTTP or SOAP though the SiperianClient may be preferred depending on the requirements and features of your network, such as tunnelling or proxies that may not work with EJB.

Feature Comparison of protocols

Feature EJB HTTP SOAP JMS
Java Code Yes;
EjbSiperianClient		 Yes;
HttpSiperianClient		 Yes;
SoapSiperianClient		 Yes;
XML String over JMS
non Java Code No Yes; see XSD Yes; see WSDL Adapter to JMS required
Transactions User or CMP controlled Each request is an atomic transaction
Performance About double the throughput of HTTP or SOAP Yes; see XSD Yes; see WSDL Adapter to JMS required
Security Application server-specific HTTPS, not with HttpSiperianClient Unknown Application server-specific
Network Application server-specific HTTPS (may offer easier routing) Application server-specific
Synchronous Yes (by default) No
Asynchronous Yes (responses can be returned in a JMS queue) Yes

Development Instructions

The sifsdk\lib folder contains jars you'll need to use SiperianClient within your application. See documentation of the SiperianClient API:
sifsdk\javadoc\index.html.

Note: Siperian classes not documented in those javadocs should not be used as they are subject to change without notification.

Library Requirements

You will need to include various libraries on your classpath depending on your usage:

All siperian-api.jar
siperian-common.jar
log4j-1.2.8.jar
HTTP or SOAP castor-1.1.1-xml
xerces-2.7.1/*.jar
HTTP commons-httpclient-2.0
SOAP axis1.3/*.jar
EJB The client jar file appropriate to the application server you are using.
Note: If you are using Websphere and EJB, you must use the IBM JVM to run your client application.

Asynchronous Requests

There are two ways to send requests to the Siperian Hub to be processed asynchronously:

  • Set the AsynchronousOptions on a request that is submitted as described above. When the request is submitted is is placed on a queue for processing. If the jmsReplyTo field is set, the response will be posted to the specified queue. If the jmsCorrelationId is set, this ID will be set on the response.
  • Place the request directly on the JMS queue: queue/siperian.sif.jms.queue. If the replyTo header is set, the response will be posted to the specified queue. If the jmsCorrelationId is set, this ID will be set on the response. Requests must be formatted as XML as specified in the XML Schema.
